sentence: Examples of eso and exo fixation disparities, and their effects on retinal images are shown in Figure 1.
An example of results from a subjective experiment is shown in Figure 2.
Figure 4 shows a schematic of the system.
The left TSLO was placed on a larger optical table and the right TSLO was mounted on an X-Y-Z adjustable instrument stage (Figure 3).

A photo of the binocular TSLO with the left system rotated for an 8° vergence demand is shown in Figure 3.Experimental protocol
Subjects were given a simple task to keep them fixating accurately.
Examples of the stimuli in the subject’s and experimenter’s views are shown in Figure 4.
We chose this method to compute the PRL because it is not prone to shifts caused by occasional losses of fixation by one eye like those shown in Figure 5.
Each eye trace is plotted relative to the PRL identified in the monocular condition: that is, 0 represents the monocular PRL horizontal location.Figure 8.
Over each new distribution composed of 400 bootstrapped PRLs, the IQR was computed along each horizontal marginal.Figure 10.
Each color represents the data from one of our subjects as indicated in Figure 9.

The error bars represent the vertical interquartile range of the PRL estimates (see Figure 8).The isoline contour was computed from these same densities by finding the contour area whose cumulative probability is equal to 68%.
The isoline contours for each condition on the master reference image are shown in Figure 6.

Figure 5 shows representative examples of the horizontal gaze directions for the left and right eyes for each binocular convergence demand during the course of a trial.
The amplitude of the sawtooth in Figure 5 indicates approximately a 0.5° rotation of the image.
The central tendencies and variation are shown in Figure 6, which shows how the position of the PRLs and ISOA in the two eyes varied across trials and conditions.
Figure 7 shows those positions for each subject and vergence demand.
Figure 8 plots the horizontal shifts in PRLs as a function of vergence demand; the left panel plots the shifts in the left eye and the right panel those in the right eye.
The left panel of Figure 9 shows that the left-eye shifts caused systematic changes in fixation disparity.
In the right panel of Figure 9 we plot previous data for demands of −2 to +10° to enable comparison with our data.
Figure 10 plots those shifts for each of our five subjects.
As shown in Figure 9, these increases in disparity were comparable to what has been found in other studies relying on objective and subjective measures.
The fixation disparities were primarily caused by shifts in fixation of the non-dominant eye, which was the left eye in all of our subjects (Figure 8).
In our study, the non-dominant eye exhibited systematic shifts in PRL with increasing vergence demand (Figure 6).

It also exhibited greater variability (Figure 6), including more frequent deviations in fixation that were large enough to place the target outside of Panum’s fusional area presumably causing loss of binocular fusion (Figure 5).
The more frequent deviations caused greater skewness in the histograms (Figure 7).

Despite this exquisite sensitivity to gaze shifts in monocular viewing, our subjects seemed to tolerate shifts in fixation loci in one eye as large as 8 minarc when they were viewing targets binocularly (Figure 9).
Examples of eso and exo fixation disparities, and their effects on retinal images are shown in Figure 1.
An example of results from a subjective experiment is shown in Figure 2.
Figure 4 shows a schematic of the system.
The left TSLO was placed on a larger optical table and the right TSLO was mounted on an X-Y-Z adjustable instrument stage (Figure 3).

A photo of the binocular TSLO with the left system rotated for an 8° vergence demand is shown in Figure 3.Experimental protocol
Subjects were given a simple task to keep them fixating accurately.
Examples of the stimuli in the subject’s and experimenter’s views are shown in Figure 4.
We chose this method to compute the PRL because it is not prone to shifts caused by occasional losses of fixation by one eye like those shown in Figure 5.
Each eye trace is plotted relative to the PRL identified in the monocular condition: that is, 0 represents the monocular PRL horizontal location.Figure 8.
Over each new distribution composed of 400 bootstrapped PRLs, the IQR was computed along each horizontal marginal.Figure 10.
Each color represents the data from one of our subjects as indicated in Figure 9.

The error bars represent the vertical interquartile range of the PRL estimates (see Figure 8).The isoline contour was computed from these same densities by finding the contour area whose cumulative probability is equal to 68%.
The isoline contours for each condition on the master reference image are shown in Figure 6.

Figure 10 plots those shifts for each of our five subjects.
As shown in Figure 9, these increases in disparity were comparable to what has been found in other studies relying on objective and subjective measures.

The more frequent deviations caused greater skewness in the histograms (Figure 7).

Figure 5 shows representative examples of the horizontal gaze directions for the left and right eyes for each binocular convergence demand during the course of a trial.
The amplitude of the sawtooth in Figure 5 indicates approximately a 0.5° rotation of the image.
The central tendencies and variation are shown in Figure 6, which shows how the position of the PRLs and ISOA in the two eyes varied across trials and conditions.
Figure 7 shows those positions for each subject and vergence demand.
Figure 8 plots the horizontal shifts in PRLs as a function of vergence demand; the left panel plots the shifts in the left eye and the right panel those in the right eye.
The left panel of Figure 9 shows that the left-eye shifts caused systematic changes in fixation disparity.
In the right panel of Figure 9 we plot previous data for demands of −2 to +10° to enable comparison with our data.
Figure 10 plots those shifts for each of our five subjects.
Figure 5 shows representative examples of the horizontal gaze directions for the left and right eyes for each binocular convergence demand during the course of a trial.
The amplitude of the sawtooth in Figure 5 indicates approximately a 0.5° rotation of the image.
The central tendencies and variation are shown in Figure 6, which shows how the position of the PRLs and ISOA in the two eyes varied across trials and conditions.
Figure 7 shows those positions for each subject and vergence demand.
Figure 8 plots the horizontal shifts in PRLs as a function of vergence demand; the left panel plots the shifts in the left eye and the right panel those in the right eye.
The left panel of Figure 9 shows that the left-eye shifts caused systematic changes in fixation disparity.
In the right panel of Figure 9 we plot previous data for demands of −2 to +10° to enable comparison with our data.
Figure 10 plots those shifts for each of our five subjects.
As shown in Figure 9, these increases in disparity were comparable to what has been found in other studies relying on objective and subjective measures.
The fixation disparities were primarily caused by shifts in fixation of the non-dominant eye, which was the left eye in all of our subjects (Figure 8).
In our study, the non-dominant eye exhibited systematic shifts in PRL with increasing vergence demand (Figure 6).

It also exhibited greater variability (Figure 6), including more frequent deviations in fixation that were large enough to place the target outside of Panum’s fusional area presumably causing loss of binocular fusion (Figure 5).
The more frequent deviations caused greater skewness in the histograms (Figure 7).

Despite this exquisite sensitivity to gaze shifts in monocular viewing, our subjects seemed to tolerate shifts in fixation loci in one eye as large as 8 minarc when they were viewing targets binocularly (Figure 9).
